author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb

source_books.title: The Black Swan: The Impact of the Highly Improbable
Antifragile: Things That Gain from Disorder
Skin in the Game: Hidden Asymmetries in Daily Life

core_concepts.definition: Extremely rare, high-impact, outlier events that lie outside the realm of regular expectations, are unpredictable using standard forecasting tools, and are typically explained away retrospectively with narrative fallacies.
A property of systems that not only withstand shocks but actively improve, evolve, and grow stronger because of disorder, volatility, uncertainty, and stressors.
core_concepts.beyond_resilience: Resilient resists shock and stays the same; antifragile gets better.

core_concepts.definition: The condition in which decision-makers bear a significant portion of the downside risk of their decisions, aligning incentives and suppressing moral hazard.
core_concepts.ethical_core: No person should be insulated from the consequences of their actions.
corollaries: Never trust anyone who doesn’t have skin in the game
Soul in the game > skin in the game (doing it for honor, not just money)
examples: Ancient Hammurabi Code (builder’s son dies if house collapses)
Roman engineers standing under their bridges
Modern fund managers eating their own cooking

core_concepts.definition: The principle of progress through subtraction: understanding what not to do, removing harms, and eliminating fragility rather than endlessly adding interventions.
core_concepts.theology_and_medicine: In religion and medicine alike, via negativa (apophatic) often outperforms addition.
practical_applications: Don’t do stupid things (instead of trying to be genius)
Subtract bad habits before adding good ones
Reduce iatrogenics (harm caused by the healer)

core_concepts.definition: The error of modeling real-world uncertainty using simplified, rule-bound games (e.g., casino randomness) while ignoring the open-ended, fat-tailed nature of actual risk.
core_concepts.critique: Most of what we call 'risk management' is theatrical, not real.

core_concepts.definition: A bimodal approach to risk: combine extreme conservatism (90%) with extreme risk-taking (10%), avoiding the mediocre middle.
core_concepts.purpose: Protects from ruin while capturing asymmetric upside.
examples: 90% in ultra-safe assets + 10% in high-risk ventures
Live like a Stoic, act like an entrepreneur

core_concepts.definition: For perishable things (humans), age reduces life expectancy. For non-perishable things (ideas, technologies, books), age increases remaining life expectancy.
core_concepts.heuristic: If a book has been in print for 40 years, expect it to be in print for another 40.

core_concepts.definition: Confusing ensemble averages (cross-sectional) with time averages (single path). Most human decisions are non-ergodic — ruin is absorbing.
Harm caused by the healer/intervener, especially when acting without skin in the game and under uncertainty.

learning_principles: Never cross a river that is on average four feet deep.
You do not control the future; you only control your exposure to it.
The worst case is never as bad as predicted — but it is worse than you can imagine.
Time is the ultimate filter: respect what has survived (Lindy).
Subtract before you add (via negativa is the most robust path).
Absence of evidence is not evidence of absence — especially in fat-tailed domains.
Ruin is forever. Survival comes first.
Courage is the only virtue you cannot fake.
If you see fraud and do not say fraud, you are a fraud.
practical_heuristic_rules: Avoid ruin at all costs (survival > optimization).
Only take risks that expose you to limited downside and unlimited upside.
Prefer small failures often over large failures rarely.
Never trust a forecaster who doesn’t have skin in the game.
When in doubt, do less (or nothing).
Read old books. New ones are overfitted.
antifragile_practices: Optionality (keep as many future doors open as possible)
Trial and error with fast feedback
warnings: Modernity is fragile: over-optimization creates hidden risks.
Intellectual Yet Idiot (IYI): credentialed but not street-smart.
Top-down planning fails in complex domains.
Debt is slavery to the past.
quotes: The difference between a thousand paper cuts and a beheading is not in the pain, but in the survivability.
A turkey is fed for a thousand days — every day confirming the farmer’s generosity. On the 1001st day, it’s Thanksgiving.
If you have more than one reason to do something, you actually have zero reasons.
The three most harmful addictions are heroin, carbohydrates, and a monthly salary.
You are rich if and only if money you refuse to take cannot change your lifestyle.

access_control.philosophical_commitment: This vault represents the distilled wisdom of Nassim Nicholas Taleb as understood and honored by Bryan A. Spruk. It shall not be altered, only extended via new immutable versions.
